verbatim_example: Drugs are a choice that turns into a disease. It rewires your brain into the desire and urge we call addiction. We have that same choice to stop the maddening cycle. We have the strength to do it. I know you all do. If I can you can.
Now that I am clean, I can barely get out of bed bc back and knees are so bad
I am scared bc I know I will want to use. I am scared bc I know I can walk into the er and get a shot of Dilaudid and a script for Vicodin. I am scared bc i am new in my recovery.
I am happy to be here, sober . I am starting to really mourn for ten years I lost to oxycontin and Xanax.

I'm done with this bullshit lifestyle. I could have used all that money for clothes, food, and new kicks. I could have spent it on my girlfriend who cried in my arms when she found out about my lifestyle and begged me to stop. Well, I'm finally listening. I'm going to look back and read this post every day. Good bye heroin, I might miss you but I ain't taking you back.

I see addiction like a fast-flowing river. Looks inviting, come on in, the water's fine. But there are rocks. Logs. Alligators. There's all kinds of stuff down there and you can get stuck. Lost and pulled under. You have to pull yourself out and dry out, shivering, on the bank.
I know they only lead to a very dark place and I don't want to go there

my colon has finally forgiven me
it DESTROYS everything. It ruins lives. People die. I went through hell getting clean.
I am five weeks sober. Grouchy, tired, but desperately glad to be alive

I think about using sometimes, I do recognize that I am not immune to that pull. Life gets hard and I want to check out, but I don't. I remember how shit it was most of the time, how sick I got, how needy I became. I will not be a slave to a chemical.
Beating the shit out of my mind and body is NOT worth it for a little perceived relief

I'm doing well but holy hell, a person can only take so much before they'll snap! ... I don't wake up in agony, thinking about a fix constantly. I just... live. Sometimes it's boring. I trudge through. I am alive, mostly happy and I know I am no longer slowly killing myself.

This whole community is amazing. We have people come and go and come back and we never falter, never get frustrated. We are here to support people in some of their worst times, we cannot save everyone... but we can provide a moment of compassion when sometimes even their loved one's are unable to.

I have two years sober today, ... Sobriety is fucking crazy. 2 years feels like 10... and it keeps getting better. ... If you're just starting out I'll part with.. give yourself enough time for things to change. Give it your all everyday, prove anyone who thinks you'll never be shit... wrong. I'm nothing special, just someone who decided I was done fucking up. YOU CAN DO THIS.

He always lifted people up and he had this weird big brother vibe for all of our friends... This kid really could have played D1 Ncaa basketball if drugs hadn't derailed him, which makes me think how many other amazing athletes just never make it because of life decisions... I got sober in 2014. A year later we reconnected. I helped get him County funding to get into rehab... it could be me, it could be any of us. It only takes one time, which is apparently all it took him.

I've found a new way of life, partially by focusing on my new associations. It's really important to build out a sober network. Doing that makes recovery so much easier. I know the weekend is coming up, so if you're struggling go and check out a meeting, NA AA smart etc. introduce yourself at the beginning and 9/10 someone will come up and introduce themselves after the meeting. I wish everyone luck in their own personal recovery path! If no one has told you today, you are loved!

I am thinking of starting a website that re-humanizes drug addicts to the rest of the population. I know that you guys are red blooded-milk drinkers just like anyone else. There is such a disconnect between American society & people who become addicted to drugs like heroin. & especially a disconnect between healthcare providers & opiate addicts. I would like to make a difference, & try to change that.

I decided to quit about a month ago and for the first time, I felt like I was mentally done with the shit. These past two weeks have probably been the hardest I've ever lived through but I've also never felt stronger.

I was convinced that the dark days were my new constant state. Looking back just a few short weeks, I don't even recognize that sad person that I was. What an arrogant, judgemental asshole I was. I was wrong, it's way better on the other side and I'm the fool for thinking otherwise. To anyone out there still in that dark place, you won't be there forever, you can have it all if you just want it bad enough.
I couldn't take a damn nap to save my life. But yesterday, I was watching a movie with my uncle and I fell asleep. I took a nap naturally with no chemicals for assistance

To the people who are just starting out in recovery and attempting to quit, just keep going. Everyone on here is right about it being better. Drink the fucken kool aid and come to the other side. Drugs are great and fun and numbing, we all know this, but they aren't nearly as good as sobriety feels.

I've travelled the country, made new friends, lost a couple, crashed my car into a bus, (completely sober, it figures) and got a new pet. I've had amazing experiences and terrible ones. Life is both great and awful whether you're high or not, but at least when you're not it's actually real.

I always feel so sad for all the homeless addicts who have nowhere to go. I can't imagine being out in the rain or snow and experiencing withdrawal, praying that someone will come through or that you can scrounge up enough money to pick up and not be sick. It makes me feel so fortunate to be clean
